Award.AwardTitle: Conference Proposal to NSF: Public Understanding and Public Engagement with Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project enables a group of U.S. researchers to collaborate with the planning for, and to attend, a workshop that the German Research Foundation (DFG) is holding on their priority program, "Science and the General Public: Understanding Fragile and Conflicting Scientific Evidence." The goal of the conference is to share theoretical approaches, emthods, and findings, leading ultimately to a research agenda on the public understanding of science and a set of empirically-tested design principles for communicating science-related information to the lay public. The meeting will be held in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation in collaboration with the German government’s research funding agency, Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) sponsored a conference held in New York City June 28 – July 1, 2011 on public understanding of science and engagement with it. Never before has the public’s access to science information been as ubiquitous and instantaneous as it is with the advent and rapid spread of the Internet. However, much of the information that the public finds on the internet creates barriers to understanding the very information and issues with which the public is concerned. During the conference, scholars and researchers from a number of different fields exchanged research findings on why this is so, how communication of science information might be improved, and how the education system might better prepare citizens to understand science information.  The fields of Communication and Media Sciences, Cognitive and Psychological Sciences,  Climate Science, Education, Journalism, Learning Sciences, Science Education, and Sociology were represented as were institutions that support informal learning (e.g., zoos and museums) and formal learning (elementary and high schools as well as colleges and universities). The conference focused on four major themes: 1. Characteristics of a scientifically informed public, 2. The understanding and evaluation of sources of scientific information, 3. The influence of the Internet and other media on Public Engagement with Science, 4. The communication and teaching of scientific information for understanding and participation. On the last day of the conference, participants formed interest groups and discussed ways in which to continue the dialogue and explore joint projects moving forward. Topics of those interest groups were Sources of Expertise, Scientific Uncertainty, Epistemic Cognition, Community Involvement in Science, Responsibility in Media and Scientific Communities. A major product of the conference is a forthcoming special issue of the journal Educational Psychologist (expected Fall, 2014).
